0.message:
Run rake bootstrap to set up your working copy.

Currently initializes & updates all git submodules

2.message:
rake bootstrap now bundle installs

Assists in getting a fresh working copy up and running
with a single command.

3.message:
Podfile specifies project path

This will allow more flexible paths where the won't have
to type the path to the install command each time.

4.message: Validate setting the pods root variable

5.message: Raise an informative error if xcodeproj is not present in Podfile, for now.

6.message: Raise an informative error when Podfile specifies xcodeproj to an invalid path

7.message: Test informative messages for missing or invalid xcodeproj

8.message: Move logic for generating PODS_ROOT to a class

9.message: Use PODS_ROOT instead of hardcoding SRCROOT/Pods in the copy resources script

10.message:
the test setup moves the config.project_pods_root in a non-standard way

I don't think this is the place to be asserting the path behavior anyway,
so I'm now just verifying that the build var gets set.

11.message: Podfile stubs now include a dummy xcodeproj setting

14.message:
Don't assume scheme for the derived data folder.
Correct an issue where the first derived path found contains a file, leading to a double forward slash in the calculated path.
Raise an ArgumentError if the configuration is missing target AND app_name, which would lead to a bad path.

15.message: Added a mode for Xcode4-style archives

16.message:
Don't validate the git repo settings, as the installer cleans it out.

(Not sure which is correct behavior, but I assumed this test was wrong)

21.message: added base structure, server settings & bot object

22.message: attemp to connect to server & join room

24.message: fix relative path for nsurl category

29.message:
Merge pull request #1 from lqi/master

Extend ChaiONE Path Helper with url support for files in document directory

32.message: Set architecture to armv6 and armv7

34.message: Extracted tag selector, as it's not ready for prime time.  Way too much churn on the design

35.message: Fixed valid architectures build error when running xcodebuild

36.message: Fixed valid architectures build error when running xcodebuild

41.message:
New CHLOG and CHLOGCALL macros.
Macros for converting deg2rad & vice-versa

44.message:
Build for i386 and armv6/7

Updated build script to run simulator and iphoneos builds

45.message: Fix build for multiple platforms/architectures.  Updated build script to run simulator and device builds.

48.message:
Add explicit armv6 & armv7 architectures.

Block based action sheet.

50.message: Sample app view controller demonstrating the modal picker.

52.message:
Add explicit backdrop to maintain the cancel area.
Allow preselecting the row.

55.message: nil out picker if we dismiss to avoid a potential crash

60.message:
Added disk cache shared object.

- Use like NSMutableDictionary
- saves to app caches dir
- objects must be NSCoding compliant

62.message: Don't become first responder on viewWillAppear

71.message: Clarification on syntax, known limitations, todo list.

77.message: Rake script for running the build (using xcodebuild-rb)

78.message: Never make a project with spaces in the name.  Ugh.

80.message: default rake task cleans & builds.  Use progress formatter

84.message: podspec now contains the right class scope

88.message: Updated pod dependency to point to ChaiOneUtils repo

90.message: Moved everything into a Classes subfolder

91.message: Added a single header file for easier importing

97.message: compute relative path from source root for the PODS_ROOT var

98.message: Use PODS_ROOT instead of SOURCE_ROOT in scripts

99.message: Store the source_root in config (if it is passed in).

101.message: Ignore hg phaseroots (generated during spec run)

106.message: Podfile stubs now include a dummy xcodeproj setting

107.message:
the test setup moves the config.project_pods_root in a non-standard way

I don't think this is the place to be asserting the path behavior anyway,
so I'm now just verifying that the build var gets set.

108.message: Use PODS_ROOT instead of hardcoding SRCROOT/Pods in the copy resources script

109.message: Move logic for generating PODS_ROOT to a class

111.message: Test informative messages for missing or invalid xcodeproj

112.message: Raise an informative error when Podfile specifies xcodeproj to an invalid path

113.message: Raise an informative error if xcodeproj is not present in Podfile, for now.

114.message: Attribution for the bacon color module.

115.message:
Merge pull request #68 from mattt/AFHTTPRequestOperationLogger

Adding spec for AFHTTPRequestOperationLogger 0.9.0

117.message: Mention the rake lint task in the readme

120.message: Added nav bar, consider page 0 for loading

136.message: ignore test runs, add ocunit2junit script

8.body:
Mine was installed similarly (I think), however my configuration is in `/Library/LaunchDaemons` and looks like this:

```
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN" "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd">
<plist version="1.0">
<dict>
	<key>EnvironmentVariables</key>
	<dict>
		<key>JENKINS_HOME</key>
		<string>/Users/Shared/Jenkins/Home</string>
	</dict>
	<key>GroupName</key>
	<string>staff</string>
	<key>KeepAlive</key>
	<true/>
	<key>Label</key>
	<string>org.jenkins-ci</string>
	<key>ProgramArguments</key>
	<array>
                <string>/bin/bash</string>
		<string>/Library/Application Support/Jenkins/jenkins-runner.sh</string>
	</array>
	<key>RunAtLoad</key>
	<true/>
	<key>UserName</key>
	<string>gaurav</string>
</dict>
</plist>
```

9.body:
Moving the plist over into `/Library/LaunchAgents` did the trick!

I read a little more about the difference between the two types of processes here, which helped:
http://reviews.cnet.com/8301-13727_7-10329211-263.html

Thanks for the assistance.

19.body:
This sounds like it would work just fine, however one of the benefits I see for CocoaPods is that all of this mess is reduced down to linking a single static library.  I've seen Xcode be so finicky about this that I'm very weary about adding new static libs haphazardly into my projects.

That said, if CocoaPods made it "just work" then I'd favor this approach.  Makes perfect sense.

31.body:
I had the :git reference, then did pod install, then committed.

Because the pod had a .git folder in it, git got confused, thinking it should have been a submodule.

On Feb 24, 2012, at 11:55 AM, Eloy Durn wrote:

> Well, it currently does do a checkout if the directory doesnt exist yet. Except in your case, which I guess is git complaining because you already had it registered as a submodule?
> 
> I wanted it to be able to handle all cases, even if some things are done manually, but its definitely the goal that that shouldnt be necessary.
> 
> --- 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
> https://github.com/CocoaPods/CocoaPods/issues/72#issuecomment-4161660

34.body:
I have it working in the example app, but there is a bit of a snag.  If you ever type `pod install` without the project argument, then everything gets regenerated with the defaults.

I'm wondering if we need some sort of `.pods` metadata file so that we can keep track of where the xcodeproj is.

35.body:
I like that anyway :)

If it finds more than one project, we can fail the install and instruct them to add one of the projects to the Podfile.

On Feb 25, 2012, at 6:13 AM, Eloy Durn wrote:

> Good point. I think we should glob the current work directory for `*.xcodeproj` and if its **just one** assume that that is the one to use, otherwise let people define the path to the xcodeproj from the Podfile.
> 
> This will be needed at some point anyways for once we support multiple xcodeprojs (multiple platforms) in one workspace anyways (see #76 and #63).
> 
> Something like:
> 
> ```Ruby
> xcodeproj 'subdir/App.xcodeproj'
> ```
> 
> For now the attribute could just be defined on the Podfile class directly, but later on we should move it to the TragetDefinition for multiple xcodeproj support.
> 
> This means that specifying the project to use to `pod install` will be deprecated.
> 
> --- 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
> https://github.com/CocoaPods/CocoaPods/pull/138#issuecomment-4172418

36.body: Also, the integration_spec was failing because it was checking for a git repository in a cloned pod, however the installer cleans out the `.git` folder.  I'm assuming that is correct behavior and the test is wrong, so I've removed this assertion in 74c8412.

37.body:
That sounds better.

Sent from my iPhone

On Mar 9, 2012, at 2:56 AM, "Eloy Durn"
<reply@reply.github.com>
wrote:

>> It will use this if a path is not provided via the installer command
>
> That behavior should be fully removed imo. I find it makes it unnecessarily hard to explain when you need to specify it and when not and even if we explain it people miss when to use it.
>
> Therefor I prefer that if an xcodeproj is not explicitly specified in the Podfile, that we just see if theres one xcodeproj in the same directory as the Podfile and, if so, use that. If not one xcodeproj is found and none is specified in the Podfile, then it should complain and exit.
>
> ---
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
> https://github.com/CocoaPods/CocoaPods/pull/154#issuecomment-4412949

52.body:
The instructions are wrong, btw.  Wondering if the symlinking should just be done in the `install` method, instead of being a caveat?

The correct post-install instructions are:

```
mkdir -p ~/Library/Application\ Support/appledoc
ln -sf /usr/local/Cellar/appledoc/2.0.5/Template/docset ~/Library/Application\ Support/appledoc
ln -sf /usr/local/Cellar/appledoc/2.0.5/Template/html ~/Library/Application\ Support/appledoc
```

> post_install do |installer|
>  installer.project.targets.each do |target|
>    target.buildConfigurations.each do |config|
>      config.buildSettings['ARCHS'] = '$(ARCHS_STANDARD_32_64_BIT)'
>      config.buildSettings['MACOSX_DEPLOYMENT_TARGET'] = '10.6'
>      config.buildSettings['GCC_ENABLE_OBJC_GC'] = 'supported'
>    end
>  end
> end
>

> https://github.com/CocoaPods/CocoaPods/issues/181#issuecomment-4596057

ruby -v

56.body:
So that's why.  Your Podfile is using the 1.9 style of hashes:

```
# 1.9 style
foo: "bar", baz: "quux"

# 1.8 style
:foo => "bar", :baz => "quux"
```

The 1.8 style hashes are still valid in 1.9, so you can just switch to that (or install ruby 1.9.3)

On Mar 20, 2012, at 9:24 AM, ooking wrote:

> ruby -v
> ruby 1.8.7 (2010-01-10 patchlevel 249) [universal-darwin11.0]
> 
> --- 
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub:
> https://github.com/CocoaPods/CocoaPods/issues/181#issuecomment-4596252

```
$(BUILT_PRODUCTS_DIR)/../Release-iphoneos

61.body:
If you've upgraded to Xcode 4.3, you need to tell the system where the new developer directory is.  I had to run this to get this gem installed:

```
sudo xcode-select -switch /Applications/Xcode.app/Contents/Developer/Platforms/MacOSX.platform/Developer/
```

Hope this helps others with the same error.

64.body:
I like that anyway :)

If it finds more than one project, we can fail the install and instruct them to add one of the projects to the Podfile.

On Feb 25, 2012, at 6:13 AM, Eloy Durn wrote:

> Good point. I think we should glob the current work directory for `*.xcodeproj` and if its **just one** assume that that is the one to use, otherwise let people define the path to the xcodeproj from the Podfile.
> 
> This will be needed at some point anyways for once we support multiple xcodeprojs (multiple platforms) in one workspace anyways (see #76 and #63).
> 
> Something like:
> 
> ```Ruby
> xcodeproj 'subdir/App.xcodeproj'
> ```
> 
> For now the attribute could just be defined on the Podfile class directly, but later on we should move it to the TragetDefinition for multiple xcodeproj support.
> 
> This means that specifying the project to use to `pod install` will be deprecated.

0.body:
I read this: https://github.com/timcharper/spork/wiki/Spork.trap_method-Jujutsu

and figured it would answer my problems.  Basically I'm running guard-spork to reload spork for env changes, and guard-rspec to automatically run my spec when it (or the related model file) change.

But if I change the model file, the change is not picked up, thus the test incorrectly reports pass/failure for various specs that depend on the changed behavior.

I have the following in my `Spork.prefork` block:

```ruby
Spork.prefork do
  ENV["RAILS_ENV"] ||= 'test'
  
  require 'rails/mongoid'
  Spork.trap_class_method(Rails::Mongoid, :load_models)
  require 'rails/application'
  Spork.trap_method(Rails::Application, :reload_routes!)
  
  # Now load our environment
  require File.expand_path("../../config/environment", __FILE__)
  require 'rspec/rails'
  ...
```

Is there something else I need to be doing, perhaps in the `each_run` block, to make sure my models are reloaded?
0.title: Mongoid Models not reloading

1.body:
I was testing a category method, and I had named my class something like `UIColor+MyAdditionsSpec.m`.  The file was not picked up by the test runner.

I'm not sure if this is a bug in Xcode 4.2 , SenTestingKit, or Kiwi, unfortunately.

Removing the `+` character from the spec filename made it work again.
1.title: Kiwi Specs don't run if the filename contains a +

3.body:
For whatever reason, the project I'm on has `$(SOURCE_ROOT)` as a folder one step up from the root of the git root.  This makes a couple of things problematic:

- The `Pods.xcconfig` sets up `PODS_ROOT` as `$(SOURCE_ROOT)/Pods`
- The `Copy Pods Resources` script directly uses `$(SOURCE_ROOT)/Pods`

In my case, I need `$(SOURCE_ROOT)/../Pods`.

If a project were to provide a custom environment var for this, where should it be defined?
3.title: Provide a way to override the PODS_ROOT path

5.body:
Looking at the source, it seems to only support string values in arrays.  Why is this?

Here's my info.plist (slightly sanitized):

````
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>
<!DOCTYPE plist PUBLIC "-//Apple//DTD PLIST 1.0//EN" "http://www.apple.com/DTDs/PropertyList-1.0.dtd">
<plist version="1.0">
<dict>
	<key>CFBuildDate</key>

	<key>CFBuildNumber</key>
	<integer>1052</integer>

	<key>CFBundleIconFiles</key>

		<string>Icon.png</string>
		<string>Icon@2x.png</string>
		<string>Icon-72.png</string>
		<string>Icon-Small.png</string>
		<string>Icon-Small@2x.png</string>
	</array>
	<key>CFBundleIdentifier</key>
	<string>com.company.appname</string>
	<key>CFBundleInfoDictionaryVersion</key>
	<string>6.0</string>
	<key>CFBundleName</key>
	<string>${PRODUCT_NAME}</string>
	<key>CFBundlePackageType</key>
	<string>APPL</string>
	<key>CFBundleShortVersionString</key>
	<string>${APP_VERSION}</string>
	<key>CFBundleSignature</key>
	<string>????</string>
	<key>CFBundleURLTypes</key>
	<array>
		<dict>
			<key>CFBundleURLName</key>
			<string></string>
			<key>CFBundleURLSchemes</key>
			<array>
				<string>facebook1234</string>
			</array>
		</dict>
		<dict>
			<key>CFBundleURLName</key>
			<string>com.companyname.appname</string>
			<key>CFBundleURLSchemes</key>
			<array>
				<string>custom_url_scheme</string>
			</array>
		</dict>
	</array>
	<key>CFBundleVersion</key>
	<string>2.3</string>
	<key>LSRequiresIPhoneOS</key>
	<true/>
	<key>LSApplicationCategoryType</key>
	<string>public.app-category.music</string>
	<key>NSMainNibFile</key>
	<string>MainWindow</string>
	<key>UIBackgroundModes</key>
	<array>
		<string>audio</string>
	</array>
	<key>UIPrerenderedIcon</key>
	<true/>
	<key>UIStatusBarHidden</key>
	<true/>
	<key>UISupportedInterfaceOrientations</key>
	<array>
		<string>UIInterfaceOrientationPortrait</string>
		<string>UIInterfaceOrientationLandscapeLeft</string>
		<string>UIInterfaceOrientationLandscapeRight</string>
		<string>UIInterfaceOrientationPortraitUpsideDown</string>
	</array>
</dict>
</plist>
````

I'm guessing it's the custom URL schemes element (since it contains dictionaries), but not really sure.

It would also be handy if the error message spat out the node that was problematic, for easier debugging
5.title: Xcodeproj chokes on my project's info.plist

6.body:
I ran into this bug today.  I have 2 pods that are arc enabled, but my project is not.  When running on a 4.3 device, I'd get errors like this:

```
Undefined symbols for architecture armv7:
"_objc_storeStrong", referenced from
```

There's some detail on this issue here:
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/8756418/static-library-with-arc-support-linked-to-non-arc-project-causing-linker-errors

Apparently there's a bug in LLVM, and it may not automatically include the library that gives support to 4.3 devices.  You can force it by including the linker flag `-fobjc-arc` (note: linker flag for the target, not for an individual files).

I think CocoaPods could detect this scenario and add the appropriate setting in `Pods.xcconfig`.

I don't believe this is an issue if the main project is configured to use ARC.
6.title: Include -fobjc-arc linker flag if any pods are arc enabled

7.body:
This is just a start.  I haven't verified this on my current project yet as the xcodeproject gem is choking on my project's plist values.

Any tips or ideas on how best to test this?

Summary of changes:

* `config` now has a `source_root` option that defaults to the `project_root`.  If an argument is passed in to the install command, `source_root` will contain the directory of the project file specified.
* `PODS_ROOT` is now set to a path relative to the passed in project
* `PODS_ROOT` is now used everywhere instead of `SOURCE_ROOT`
7.title: Compute PODS_ROOT Path relative to xcode project folder

9.body:
Starting to make my relative path changes here so it stays in sync with master.

The direction I'm heading is this:

* Add a `xcodeproj "subdir/myapp.xcodeproj"` setting (optional) in the `Podfile`
* It will use this if a path is not provided via the installer command
* The `PODS_ROOT` var will be calculated relative to the Xcode project path provided (either in the Podfile or in the command line arg.
9.title: Relative pod root

10.body:
I wanted to be able to take advantage of custom subdomains for secure URLs, such as "https://secure.mysite.com" or piggy-back on Heroku's SSL.

Usage:

```ruby
class FooController < ApplicationController
   force_ssl :host => "secure.mysite.com", :only => :index
   # ... 
end
```

It strips out the `:host` key before passing off the options to the `before_filter` method.
10.title: Add optional host option to force_ssl
